last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21284798
The director did not change at the half way point. Imanishi was in charge of the show alongside Mitsuko Kase from the second episode, and had joint director status until Kase left after episode 6. Imanishi was involved in storyboarding from episode 2 as well, which is usually where directors make themselves most known during a production. The departure of Kase is probably what you're thinking of as the primary cause for the change in direction of the show, since Imanishi was now in sole control, but he'd been partnered with Kase from episode 2 as director.

Director:
Mitsuko Kase (eps 1-7)
Takashi Imanishi (eps 2-13)

Storyboard:
Kazuki Akane (eps 7, 11)
Mitsuko Kase (eps 1, 5, 8)
Shinichiro Watanabe (eps 3, 6, 10)
Takashi Imanishi (eps 2, 4, 9, 12-13)

last_replies.name: JackTrade
last_replies.com:
>>21284564
>why would they do such a bad job of it though
Every reencode group does a bad job of it, by virtue of not doing anything whatsoever. Literally each and every one of them (yes, literally all) just grab video from the release people already use, then run it through Handbrake (sometimes MeGUI or StaxRip if they're feeling spicy) on higher CRF than the originals, oftentimes using HEVC for good measure (clueless downloaders slurp that shit down). As long as people see HD or 1080p or something, and notice it's smaller than the original, most people just grab it without thinking it's worse video quality (since many still seem to equate resolution with quality).

The rationale they use is that not everyone has a computer that can decode higher quality releases, or have enough HDD space, or that they're playing it on a phone that can't decode it. But those excuses fall flat - any PC in the past decade (or phone in the past half if not more) can decode anything you throw at it just fine, and HDD space is literally dirt cheap. If you can't afford it, unironically get a job. Besides, using Yamato III as an example, their source (I'm assuming Sandaphon?) is only less than 4GiB larger. If you're counting individual gigs, you probably need a new drive, or need to stop trying to archive shows.

These guys don't encode video, they don't remux audio, they don't tidy up subs. They're just vultures that click a button on their PC, jerk to some catgirl hentai, then when it's done post it and act like they're doing a service to people. [Not all of them are bad - I used to talk to the GXS guys and they were okay, and Reaktor's pretty chill - but some are active scumbags that ask for money. Can't say for GXS since their website looks to be dead.]

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21284456
Nope, no Tankobons for the Golion manga. Even though it was serialized in TV Land (a monthly magazine) from April 1981 to February 1982 (昭和56年4月号 through 昭和57年2月号), a span of 10 months. Given how the only chapter of the Golion manga completely found is only 15 pages long, it's safe to assume each chapter is shorter than your average 19-page-long shounen manga chapter. For example, pic related is a ToC from July 1981 (昭和56年7月号). That month's chapter of the Golden manga lasts from page 183 to 195, or 12 pages long.
We don't know which issue the found 15-page chapter is from. As for the partially lost chapter printed on pink paper (>>21268514, >>21268516, >>21268519), we know it was in the April 1981 issue of TV Land.

I wonder what other treasures could be found in these issues of TV Land?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21284513
Nice info. Bonkers how much is lost. One of the earliest serialized piloted combining robots (大マシン,『月刊少年』 1967-1968) didn't get a tankoubon until 2001 and even then it was only republished that one time. It was piloted by a family, used a telephone gimmick for different weapons, combined mid-air and switched parts like Jeeg. You have to wonder how much hidden mecha history there is out there.

threads.sub: If you were to change something on a Mobile Suit, what would you do?
threads.com:
If you were to add, change, or remove something from a MS, what would you alter?

Mobile suits are walker infantry, but also tanks. To make them more tanky, I've been experimenting with my Zaku 2 Model;

RPG / Heat shell cages - Syrian War / Ukraine War / WW2
ERA plating - Modern RU stuff.
I also made embedded smoke launchers. Should I look into trying to make these add on armor things better or 'dont mess with whats perfect?'

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21283237
>>21283477
Although newer or alternative engines were available, they kept the same one for newer Zudahs and unsurprisingly the problem never went away completely. While swapping out the engine is probably not a simple rebuild, it at least doesn't require redesigning the entire suit. The Zudah F actually doubles the number of faulty engines. It could be argued that it's less likely to destroy itself since it can run both engines at a lower output rating to achieve same or better performance, but it still seems sillier than say just adopting the completely safe engines that Zimmad used for the Rick Dom or other suits.

Zaku I is an example of a functional machine but its design didn't allow for much in the way of improvements unless they completely rebuilt the machine or if the modifications were external, because the internal structure left very little space for changes or improvements. It never had the expandibility or adaptability of other suits unless the upgrades were going to be entirely external (new gun and backpack in the case of the Zaku Sniper).

threads.com:
So I finally got around to start watching the original series, just wanted to make a thread to ask dumb questions about the show as I think about them.

So in episode 14, a bunch of infantry stick a bunch of bombs on the Gundam and they're desperately trying to get the bombs off. What the hell are they and why are they so destructive? The Gundam's been basically indestructible up to here, and one bomb just blew the shield to shreds.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21281283

I think so, yes. I prefer the TV show to it personally, but that's because I really like the TV show generally. The novels still do some cool things though and if you prefer things to have a more military bent, they probably scratch that itch since the crew of the White Base is enlisted from the start and drop all the refugees they take on from Side 7 at Luna II almost immediately; including Fraw and the 3 orphan kids. Who don't have much of a part in the story after that. The novels also skip some things in the show or change them entirely. It never goes to Earth for instance, and the war may not even have touched it beyond the colony drop (i.e. no invasion), Sayla never becomes a pilot and so on.

Amuro is more of a soldier too, and becomes the White Base's flight commander as well as it's central mobile suit pilot, leading a small group including obviously Kai and Hayato, but also including some fighter craft for much of the second novel. I found it quite interesting to see him become more of a military man; especially when the occasional appearance Fraw makes is her working in a military factory on Luna II while taking care of the kids. There's less focus on Amuro's relationship with Bright etc. because of it, but more on how Amuro relates to other characters, Sayla especially; though she's never presented as his primary love interest despite how much people act like it. She's someone he rebounds to after Lalah dies, basically.

>Why won't anyone answer my question?
Try being specific, especially about your materials and process. Post images whenever possible; even if the kit/part looks bad, you are more likely to get help posting images.

>Why are my pictures sideways?
4chan strips EXIF data from images when they're uploaded to the site from your phone, including the orientation display tag. To fix this, save your images separately, or use an app that will rotate and save the images for you.
One commonly used app that works well on Android:

>>21280223
No one's ever said anything, but I'm assuming a lot comes down to Nagahama dying so early. The series were heavily associated with him, so there's an element of respect for the deceased in there, as well as the fact of him not being around to keep directing in the 80s/90s means there's no easy way for new fans to come in.

Like, Tomino kept directing, so he has this huge body of work and if you get in through any of it you'll probably wander back to Zambot/Daitarn/Ideon eventually. If Nagahama had lived, he'd probably have an equally huge body of work drawing in new people throughout the 80s/90s/00s. That keeps the old works in the public consciousness and encourages later investment. Instead the only way for potential new fans to come in is SRW. Which works, as most people here can probably attest, but it's not as high-profile.

Then there's the part where Gundam got huge and changed everything. Gundam 0079 owes a massive amount to the Robot Romance series, but Gundam got the movies and the New Anime Century, it got the gunpla, and it got the sequels. Just ended up overshadowing Robot Romance.

So yeah. The guy most associated with them died pretty much right after they finished, that's why.

threads.com:
What is the best way to download (or buy) Force Five material these days?
Specifically looking for their adaptation of Danguard Ace, because I can't find it anywhere online except for a few bootleg DVD stores and a couple of dead Youtube links.
Internet Archive hosts nearly everything else from the anthology (along with a truckload of other old dubs), but the only entries pertaining to their version of Danguard are recordings of the theme song and a scanned VHS sleeve.
One of the comments in pic related kinda makes me wonder if the bootleg BD author found some episodes of the elusive Hawaiian or Filipino english dubs, though it’s more likely that they just pinched lines from the 2013 re-dub films, had to source from tapes of highly varying quality/condition, or even re-recorded lines himself. Considering that Asuka The Disc Dog has a reputation for selling disks with missing or broken audio tracks such things wouldn’t be too surprising.

As for Danguard itself it’s a pretty great show from what I’ve seen through the aforementioned newer dub (fun MOTW action and adventures, good melodrama, crisp animation) and I’d like to have some kind of an alternative to the ARR subs, in case they’re just as bad as some of the group’s other output.

I have no nostalgic attachment to any of these shows or dubs, I just happen to like a few 70s anime and also find the Yank dubs kinda interesting in terms of how well their source materials survived the edits and low-rent voice acting.

While I’m at it, what are your favorite ”pre-Akira” dubs of /m/-related media, be it for genuine quality/charm or just something to snicker at?
M&M Communication’s Mazinger Z is a pretty strong and faithful effort, complete with Isao Sasaki’s translated songs, and as a fan of ”dad jokes” I find ZIV’s second volume of Captain Harlock pretty funny at times. If I can’t laugh /with/ the jokes I'll at least have a hearty chuckle at the fact that it was an officially licensed mass-market tape.

>>21281804
The Streamline dub of Akira is usually referred to as the genesis of the "modern" anime dub, releasing long before companies like Central Park Media, VIZ, or Media Blasters started to set up shop. Prior to that anime dubs were typically heavily localized/trimmed down versions of shows resulting in things like Voltron or Astro Boy being seen as the standard for bringing over anime. One of the few exceptions to that was Robotech, or at least the Macross portion of it which still manages to be a fairly legitimate attempt to bring over an anime during the 80s.

threads.com:
it's one of the worst turret designs I have ever seen. It's attached to the hull with a mere metal plate with nothing to support it structurally wise. And the main gun is positioned in such a way that it would have been outright impossible to load any shells into it. The machine guns, despite their mountings are effectively coaxial MGs because the way the ammo belts are loaded into them limits the traverse. And last but not least it possesses no optics, and the only ones visible are mounted on the hull, effectively limiting the Vanagandr's environmental awareness to directly in front of it.

Overall, neither do I understand why the Feds kept it as their main AFV, it's such an incompetent design it would have worked better as a Republican vehicle. I have a hard time believing that the same nation that designed the Lowe designed this. The Vanagandr IMO should have just been a manned version of the Lowe, with a different paintjob and more blocky design, not this demonic mechanical spider from hell.

Instructor H was apparently directly funded by the Winner family, apparently, yes. It's kind of difficult to pin down, since the specific history is never explicitly shown so far as I know but the Episode Zero manga chapter about Quatre's past does have him talk to Instructor H after meeting the Maganac Corp, before Instructor H says that he'll take refuge in Quatre's home and Quatre bidding the Maganac Corp farewell with the promise that he'll meet them again in future. >>21284315
The Original Generation games have a decent difficulty curve, the GBA games (OG1 and OG2) are harder but the PS2 remake (OGs) has way better production values
Alpha Gaiden has a good level of difficulty and a really fun storyline but it's not totally standalone if that matters, although if you've played OG1 and know basic Gundam stuff you're more or less caught up
A Portable is the hardest post-Classic-era game, which still isn't THAT hard but you might want to try a few other games first
GC has decent difficulty but suffers from some weird pacing and story issues, but if you like OYW Gundam you're in luck because that's like a third of the game
J on the GBA is easy
W on the DS is probably even easier but it's also a lot of fun and one of the big "best SRW ever" contenders
You could also just say fuck it and play the classic games (2, 3, EX are translated) which are primitive but enjoyable if you're into early SRPGs jank and all, there's also Masoukishin on SFC which is the first original-only game with a more in-depth story than the other early games

>>21281794
Guncannon was built as a heavily armored MS with cannons for support fire. Works well for its purpose but since it's an early design and made out of luna titanium, it's an expensive prototype like the Gundam that isn't good for mass production. So to develop a cheaper fire support MS, the Feds decide to start differently and look toward the GM. The GM Cannon takes some ideas from the Guncannon but is cheaper and easier to mass produce. Like the GM it's a light-weight MS and has economical titanium armor, so in order to better fit the fire support role they had to give it thicker and stronger legs for more stability on the ground and even then it only has one cannon to save costs and reduce recoil. There's a version of the GM Cannon that removes the heavy legs and adds extra leg thrusters for better space mobility.

The GM Cannon II is the pinnacle of the line and the very last model they built, it's built with heavy armor all over but still made of titanium so it's not too expensive, has lots of extra thrusters so it's not too sluggish in space movement, and the twin beam cannons are much more destructive than the old projectile cannons, although they lose the ability for indirect-fire. The GM Cannon II is the best one for space combat, although it's not bad for land combat either.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21276265
Curved armor is traditionally better for deflecting certain types of weapons and relatively basic projectiles, but is also traditionally more time-consuming to manufacture compared to a basic flat plate. The last time that armor shape and curve made a real difference for defensive purposes was like maybe 50 to 75 years ago for some armored vehicles and tanks, since then offensive and defensive tech has evolved to the point that relatively small weapon systems can penetrate basic armor extremely well regardless of thickness and shape, and armor tech has evolved towards composite materials and active protection instead of relying purely on thickness and shape.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21281665
So it's still useful, just not enough to be considered worth the time or effort?
And what about for body armor, where active protection isn't really an option?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21281692
Still useful especially for lighter or lower cost vehicles that can't afford to carry a lot of weight and armor to begin with, but there are other more effective defenses than just shape.

As far as infantry armor goes, most infantry don't wear a lot of rigid armor to begin with. There is thick and heavy infantry armor for things like protection against shrapnel and small explosive fragments, but it's mainly round and curved to fit the body because it's easier to move around, infantry armor doesn't really benefit from being square and blocky.
